user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_connection_close_:
```c
void
MHD_connection_close_ (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                       enum MHD_RequestTerminationCode termination_code)
{
  struct MHD_Daemon *daemon = connection->daemon;
  struct MHD_Response *resp = connection->rp.response;

  mhd_assert (! connection->suspended);
#ifdef MHD_USE_THREADS
  mhd_assert ( (! MHD_D_IS_USING_THREADS_ (daemon)) || \
               MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_current_thread_ (connection->tid) );
#endif /* MHD_USE_THREADS */
  if ( (NULL != daemon->notify_completed) &&
       (connection->rq.client_aware) )
    daemon->notify_completed (daemon->notify_completed_cls,
                              connection,
                              &connection->rq.client_context,
                              termination_code);
  connection->rq.client_aware = false;
  if (NULL != resp)
  {
    connection->rp.response = NULL;
    MHD_destroy_response (resp);
  }
  if (NULL != connection->pool)
  {
    MHD_pool_destroy (connection->pool);
    connection->pool = NULL;
  }

  MHD_connection_mark_closed_ (connection);
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I inspected the entire MHD_connection_close_ function. There are no calls to memcmp or any other function that compares C-style null-terminated strings. The code only performs: pointer/NULL checks (e.g. NULL != daemon->notify_completed, NULL != resp, NULL != connection->pool), boolean/enum checks and assignments (connection->rq.client_aware, mhd_assert, termination_code), function calls (notify_completed, MHD_destroy_response, MHD_pool_destroy, MHD_connection_mark_closed_), and thread-related assertions. None of these compare character arrays or use memcmp to compare strings, so there are no fragments that violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 in this function.
